title: As a Commercial or hobby livestock keeper in England, Scotland and Wales, I need to know what I must do if test results confirm that my cattle has bovine tuberculosis (TB) or there is suspicion of disease, so that I comply with the animal health and welfare regulations for TB disease control (101306)

details.benefit: I comply with the animal health and welfare regulations for TB disease control
details.goal: know what I must do if test results confirm that my cattle has bovine tuberculosis (TB) or there is suspicion of disease
details.impact: Has serious consequences for your users and/or their customers
justifications: The government is legally obliged to provide it
It's inherent to a person's or an organisation's rights and obligations
It's something that people can do or it's something people need to know before they can do something that's regulated by/related to government
There is clear demand for it from users
It's straightforward advice that helps people to comply with their statutory obligations
met_when: Knows that a veterinary office or an Animal Health and Veterinary Laboratories Agency inspector will carry out a disease investigation of his cattle
Knows that movement restrictions will be put in place which will prevent the farmer from moving cattle
Understands what is meant by a TB test reactor and an inconclusive reactor
Knows that reactor cattle will have to be slaughtered and he must present the documentation and correct cattle for collection
Knows that he must keep reactor cattle away from the rest of the herd until they are taken away to be slaughtered

Knows that he must keep inconclusive reactor cattle away from the rest of the herd until they have: undergone the required number of tests (clear) or, if on subsequent tests they become reactor animals, until they are taken away to be slaughtered
Knows that he can claim compensation for slaughtered cattle and knows there is further information on valuations in England, Scotland and Wales
Knows that he can choose to have reactor cattle privately slaughtered

Knows that milk from reactor cattle in a herd under restrictions cannot be sold for human consumption, and that milk from non-reactor cattle from herds under restrictions must only be sold if it meets certain requirements, and that different requirements apply to sheep and goat milk
Knows that milk quotas from his herd may need to be managed and knows there is further information
Knows he must clean and disinfect buildings, equipment and fitting that may have come into contact with the reactor cattle, or their faeces and milk
Knows that Short Interval Tests will be carried out on the remaining cattle to confirm whether the cattle are Officially TB Free and movement restrictions can be lifted
Knows that there are a number of ways to continue trading while under restrictions and how to apply for general and specific licences
Knows there is further information on what happens if TB is identified in a herd in England, Scotland and Wales (link to leaflets)
Knows there is further information on what the government is doing to control bovine TB
Knows who to contact for advice and support
knows there is further information about bovine TB and how it is identified and how it is spread
